litllm

The goal of litllm is to help you mine pdfs for scholarly analysis.

Installation

You can install the development version of litllm from GitHub with:

# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("avahoffman/litllm")

Getting started 

library(litllm)

litllm uses the OpenAI API. You‚Äôll need an API key and internet connection to use it. Check that you have an API key saved in your environment:

ll_check_api_key()
#> Looks like you have a key stored!üéâ
#> If you are having issues later, the key could be entered incorrectly or may no longer be active on OpenAI's API interface.

Note: The OpenAI API costs money. It is very cheap (around $0.80 for analyzing 100 pdfs), but you‚Äôll need to add credits through their interface.

Create a subdirectory in your working directory. We typically call ours ‚Äúpdf/‚Äù. Add the pdf files for any publications you‚Äôd like to analyze to this directory.

Note: We recommend starting with ~2 files so you can make sure everything is working as expected.

Getting authors and titles

The first thing you might want to do is iterate through all your pdf files, finding the article‚Äôs title and author information:

# look at files in the "pdf/" directory
author_df <- ll_extract_authors("pdf/")

ll_extract_authors() produces a tibble with a column ‚Äúpaper_id‚Äù (the file name), ‚Äútitle‚Äù (the article title), and ‚Äúauth‚Äù (individual author information). Each author will be on a separate row.
